Mindful Practices: Course 2
Introduction to SEL

Safety: A Prerequisite for SEL

Before SEL can be addressed at school, educators must ensure that their classrooms are safe and structured across three domains: physical, emotional, and mental.

  • Physical
  • Emotional
  • Mental

Physical Safety

Physical safety refers to the protection of all stakeholders, including families, caregivers, students, school staff, and the community, from violence, theft, and exposure to weapons and threats, in order to establish a secure learning environment.

Emotional Safety

Emotional safety refers to an experience in which one feels:

  • Safe to form close bonds with others and express emotions
  • Secure and confident to take risks
  • Challenged and excited to try something new

Mental (Psychological) Safety

Mental (psychological) Safety can be defined as:

A shared belief that the team is safe for interpersonal risk taking.” — Amy Edmonson, Harvard Business School Professor

Mental (psychological) Safety includes:

  • Dignity and respect for others: Serving basic needs for the sense of self-worth and self-esteem
  • Security, integrity and autonomy of the person: Serving the need to feel safe both physically and psychologically
  • Organizational justice: Serving the need to feel that one belongs to a community in which there is respect for due process and fair procedures

For more information about mental (psychological) safety, take a few minutes to read this article.
